column4: Description
column5: Associated general approach tag (specific practice tags only)
column6: Alternate tag category (specific practice tags only)

column4: Canopy school ID number assigned by the Christensen Institute
Canopy nominator ID number(s) assigned by the Christensen Institute
Indicates whether the school confirmed the data
Name of the school
City where the school is located
State where the school is located
School district
Indicates whether the entity represented by the NCES ID is a larger entity than the school represented by Canopy data.
Name of nominator(s)
Nominator's response to "What makes this school notable? Why are you excited to nominate it?"
School leader's response to "What is your school's core purpose?"
School leader's response to "Would you like to describe your school's model in your own words?"
Stage of the school's model as reported by the nominator
Years of implementation of the school's model as reported by the school leader
Students learn both online and in-person, in which both learning enviroments are connected to provide an integrated learning experience.
A systems model in which teaching and learning are designed to ensure students are becoming proficient by advancing on demonstrated mastery.

The school puts historically marginalized students at the center, with the goal of improving supports and outcomes for these students. Examples of marginalized students include: students with learning differences, students in foster care, students in the justice system, students with low academic performance.
Students learn through real-world experiences inside and outside the classroom (e.g. internships and apprenticeships, service projects, projects in the community, career training).
The school makes creative use of staffing, systems, and resources to support student-centered learning.
Students have ownership over their learning by setting learning goals, initiating action toward those goals, and reflecting on their growth.
Students learn through the creative process of design, resulting in either physical or digital creations.
Students learn through answering complex questions or solving for real-world problems. Also called problem-based learning or inquiry-based learning.

The school defines student success beyond traditional measures such as GPA, and assesses students along the expanded definition of success. (May include career readiness, social-emotional skills, purpose and agency, etc.)
The school creates a culture supportive of students' social and emotional development (e.g. self-management, social awareness, relationship skills, etc).
Educators optimize teaching and differentiate to effectively instruct a diverse group of students, regardless of whether students have an Individualized Education Program (IEP).

Schools seek to remove barriers to student success by locating, partnering, coordinating, and helping students access comprehensive services that complement and are aligned with effective instruction.
Students rotate through stations on a fixed schedule, where at least one of the stations is an online learning station.
Students learn at home via online coursework and lectures, and teachers use class time for teacher-guided practice or projects.
Students rotate through stations on a fixed schedule, where at least one of the stations is an online learning station located in a dedicated computer lab.

Students rotate through online and other stations on individual schedules set by a teacher or software algorithm. Students do not necessarily rotate to every station; they rotate only to the activities scheduled on their playlists.

Students move on fluid schedules among learning activities according to their needs. Online learning is the backbone of student learning, and teachers provide support and instruction on a flexible, as-needed basis.
Students take an online course with an online teacher in addition to other face-to-face courses, which often provides students with more flexibility over their schedules.
Students complete the majority of coursework online at home or outside of school, but attend school for required face-to-face learning sessions with a teacher.
Students have more than one opportunity to demonstrate their learning in order to show they have achieved mastery.
Students advance to new topics when they have demonstrated mastery of previous competencies, rather than advancing with only a minimal passing grade.

In assessments, students apply knowledge or demonstrate a skill rather than selecting a correct answer on a test. Performance tasks are often authentic, e.g. developing a real proposal to city planners for a new park.
Grades are reported on a standards-based report card. Grading policies allow and encourage revision until mastery of the competency, rather than penalizing mistakes.
The school allows students to complete assessments when they are ready, rather than all at once on a fixed schedule.
A transparent learning framework is used to align instruction and assessment. What proficiency looks like at each performance level is available to students and families.

column3: commitment to equity in strategic plan
column4: The school's strategic plan includes an explicit commitment to equity including clear goals, a plan to meet them, methods of assessing progress, and accountability to marginalized students and families.

column3: reallocation of resources for those most in need
column4: Example: assigning most experienced and highest skilled teachers to students needing the most help.
Design and innovation prioritizes the needs of historically marginalized students and families. Marginalized people are leaders, participants, and beneficiaries in the design process.

Restorative practices are used to resolve conflict and strengthen relationships among individuals and within communities. (In contrast to reacting to harmful or hurtful behavior with punishment or suspension.)
Pedagogy and curriculum are continually adapted to be relevant to the cultural environment and background of students attending the school.
For example: ensuring marginalized students are receiving appropriately challenging material; recruitment of underrepresented students for AP or IB courses.
Gifted programs are eliminated and barriers to AP removed so that no student is barred from accessing these opportunities.

column3: supports for students off-track for graduation
column4: The school goes above and beyond to support students off-track for graduation through additional resources and creative approaches.

column3: supports for high-poverty and homeless students
column4: The school goes above and beyond to support high poverty and homeless students through additional resources and creative approaches.
The school goes above and beyond to support immigrant and refugee students through additional resources and creative approaches.
The school goes above and beyond to support English Language Learners through additional resources and creative approaches.
The school makes creative use of human capital, e.g. through a tutor residency model, outside experts, master teachers or teacher mentors, etc.
Design maximizes for flexibility and student choice, e.g. multi-purpose spaces, moveable walls, furniture can be arranged in different configurations, etc.
A non-traditional approach to schedule that aligns with the school's mission and goals.
The school has created systems and routines to continuously monitor progress and tailor learning activities.
The school has adopted high quality instructional materials (e.g. green rating on EdReports or equivalent)
The school has a coherent strategy for delivering core curriculum using free, open resources.
Classrooms include students of many ages, rather than grouping them by age or grade band.
The school allows students to take home school-owned devices.
Data from multiple platforms or software programs is integrated in a "data dashboard" reflecting overall student learning and progress.
Students set and pursue their own learning goals, as well as self-assess their progress.
Students determine their own pace in learning rather than being required to move at the same pace as a whole group.
Students identify and follow unique learning pathways that are relevant to their interests and passions.
Profiles may include how the student is performing, as well as personal factors like who they are, what inspires them, and how they best learn.
Students plan and lead a meeting including parents and teachers to discuss the student's learning and growth. (As opposed to parent-teacher conferences without students present.)
Students (and families) can access their own learning and assessment data in real time.

column3: projects as primary method of learning
column4: Projects are a central approach to learning core content and skills, rather than added on as extra activities once core content is covered.
column5: project-based learning; experiential, work-based & place-based learning; maker & design-centered learning

column4: Projects are developed by students with teacher advisement. Students are likely to be working on diverse project topics and goals.
column5: project-based learning; experiential, work-based & place-based learning; maker & design-centered learning

column4: Projects and learning activities develop knowledge and skills across multiple subject areas and highlight connections between subject area domains.
column5: project-based learning; experiential, work-based & place-based learning; maker & design-centered learning

column4: Student projects address real-world problems (e.g. homelessness in their city, or a marketing challenge faced by a real company).
column5: project-based learning; experiential, work-based & place-based learning; maker & design-centered learning

column4: Students independently present their projects, reflect on their learning, and share progress towards their goals for an audience.
column5: project-based learning; experiential, work-based & place-based learning; maker & design-centered learning

column3: portfolios and evidence of student work
column4: Students collect and share evidence of their work over time to demonstrate their learning and growth.
column5: project-based learning; experiential, work-based & place-based learning; maker & design-centered learning

column4: The school offers career-oriented learning opportunities inside and/or outside the school system, e.g. career tech and vocational training, interview practice, internships and apprenticeships, etc.
column5: project-based learning; experiential, work-based & place-based learning; maker & design-centered learning

column3: credit for learning outside the classroom
column4: Students can earn academic credit for learning experiences outside of the school (e.g. internship, service learning, training, etc).
column5: project-based learning; experiential, work-based & place-based learning; maker & design-centered learning

column4: Students engage in meaningful community service to enrich the learning experience, learn civic responsibility, and strengthen their communities.
column5: project-based learning; experiential, work-based & place-based learning; maker & design-centered learning

column3: foundation in local knowledge, heritage, culture
column4: The school uses local knowledge, skills, issues, heritage, culture, and landscapes as the foundation for studying subjects across the curriculum.
column5: project-based learning; experiential, work-based & place-based learning; maker & design-centered learning

column4: Local learning serves as a model for understanding global challenges, opportunities, and connections.
column5: project-based learning; experiential, work-based & place-based learning; maker & design-centered learning

column4: Students engage in design thinking, a structured framework for identifying challenges, gathering information, generating potential solutions, refining ideas, and testing solutions.
column5: project-based learning; experiential, work-based & place-based learning; maker & design-centered learning

column4: The school has developed partnerships with businesses and the community, which may help facilitate experiential learning, internships, mentorships, etc.
column5: project-based learning; experiential, work-based & place-based learning; maker & design-centered learning

column4: Students can access a space and/or set of tools for use in building and designing creations.
column5: project-based learning; experiential, work-based & place-based learning; maker & design-centered learning

column4: The school uses measures for students' readiness to enter and complete college.
The school uses measures for students' readiness to enter the workforce and pursue a career path.

column3: measures for deeper learning & 21st century skills
column4: The school uses measures for deeper learning and 21st century skills e.g. communication, collaboration, academic content mastery, etc.
The school uses measures for students' development of purpose and agency.
The school uses measures for social-emotional and noncognitive skills e.g. self-management, social awareness, relationship skills, etc.
The school uses measures for school climate/culture to learn how students experience the school culture.

column3: commitment to whole child or SEL in strategic plan
column4: Development of the whole child and social-emotional competencies are a core part of the school's strategic plan.
The school has adopted a formal classroom curriculum for social and emotional learning outside of academic subjects.
The school integrates social and emotional learning throughout the academic curriculum (in contrast to a stand-alone SEL curriculum).
Dialogue circles are gatherings in which all participants sit in a circle facing each other to facilitate open, direct communication.
Small groups of students meet regularly (daily or weekly, over multiple years) with adult advisors to set learning goals, reflect on progress, and build positive relationships.

column3: hiring practices in support of student success
column4: The school's hiring process prioritizes candidates who bring mindsets that all students can succeed at the highest levels regardless of prior performance.
Teachers develop assignments and learning experiences that are relevant to each student's interests and contextualized to their lives.

column3: access to information in multiple formats
column4: Teachers offer students access to information and materials in multiple formats e.g. print, online, video, audio, hands-on, etc.
Students can demonstrate mastery in multiple ways (e.g. portfolio, oral presentation, test, group project, etc).
Accommodations traditionally reserved for students with an IEP are available to all students.
Data analytics are accessible to teachers, understandable by teachers, and are used by teachers to inform instruction.
Content is adapted to individual learners (may be accomplished using adaptive learning software).
The school connects students with adults in and outside of the school for 1:1 mentoring.
The school offers (or partners to offer) comprehensive counseling and mental health services for students.
The school offers (or partners to offer) comprehensive physical health services for students.
The school offers (or partners to offer) services that benefit families and the community at large, e.g. adult learning, childcare, family counseling.
The school is open outside of normal hours and during vacations to support learning and offer services.
The school's confirmation response for general approach tags submitted by the nominator(s).
The school's confirmation response for specific practice tags if they were submitted by the nominator(s).

Nominator response(s) to why they evaluated the tags as such.

School leader response(s) to why they evaluated the tags as such.
NCES School ID number
State ID number for the school
School's website

A classification of schools based on the type of instruction conducted by the school. Each school is assigned only one type. The types are: (1) regular school, (2) special education school, (3) vocational education school, (4) alternative/other school, and (5) reportable program (self-contained within a school, but does not have its own principal)

Indicates whether the school is a charter school. A charter is a school providing free public elementary and/or secondary education to eligible students under a specific charter granted by the state legislature or other appropriate authority, and designated by such authority to be a charter school.

Indicates whether the school is a magnet school. A magnet is a special school or program designed to attract students of different racial/ethnic backgrounds for the purpose of reducing, preventing, or eliminating racial isolation (50 percent or more minority enrollment); and/or to provide an academic or social focus on a particular theme (e.g., science/mathematics, performing arts, gifted/talented, or foreign language).
Indicates if the school does not offer any grade levels
Indicates if the school offers pre-K
Indicates if the school offers kindergarten
Indicates if the school offers first grade
Indicates if the school offers second grade
Indicates if the school offers third grade
Indicates if the school offers fourth grade
Indicates if the school offers fifth grade
Indicates if the school offers sixth grade
Indicates if the school offers seventh grade
Indicates if the school offers eighth grade
Indicates if the school offers ninth grade
Indicates if the school offers tenth grade
Indicates if the school offers eleventh grade
Indicates if the school offers twelfth grade
Indicates if the school offers thirteenth grade (a fifth year of high school)
Indicates if the school has ungraded students
Indicates if the school offers adult education
The lowest grade level offered by the school
The highest grade level offered by the school

This variable is derived and describes the general characteristic of the school. Schools were assigned to one of three main values (Elementary, Middle, and High).  All level assignments were based on the lowest grade and highest grade reported for the school.
Total student enrollment at the school (CCD SY 16-17)

Total of Racial/Ethnic Categories

Indicates whether the school provides The Free and Reduced-Price Lunch Program. This is a program under the School Lunch Act that provides cash subsidies for free or reduced-price meals to students based on family size and income criteria. Participation in the program depends on income, and eligibility is often used to estimate student needs.

Indicates whether the school is located in an urban, suburban, or rural context. This variable was determined by the Christensen Institute based on the local_original variable. "City" codes were categorized as Urban, "Suburb" codes were categorized as Suburban, and "Rural" and "Town" codes were categorized as rural.

An indication of school’s location relative to a populous area according to CCD SY 16-17 data. The locales assigned to school districts are based on the locale code of their schools, weighted by the size of the schools’ membership.
Count of students eligible to participate in the Free and Reduced-Price Lunch Program under the National School Lunch Act (see lunch_program description above for details)
Percentage of students eligible to participate in the Free and Reduced-Price Lunch Program (see lunch_program description above for details)
The unduplicated count of students in membership whose National School Lunch Program (NSLP) eligibility has been determined through direct certification
Percentage of students in membership whose National School Lunch Program (NSLP) eligibility has been determined through direct certification

A school designated under appropriate state and federal regulations as being high poverty and eligible for participation in programs authorized by Title I of P.L. 107–110. A Title I eligible school is one in which the percentage of children from low-income families is at least as high as the percentage of children from low-income families served by the LEA as a whole or that the LEA has designated as Title I eligible because 35 percent or more of the children are from low-income families.
Total student enrollment at the school (CRDC SY 16-17)
Percentage of students qualifying under IDEA (students with disabilities), as reported by CRDC SY 15-16
Percentage of students qualifying under LEA (English language learners), as reported by CRDC SY 15-16
Note: further references for NCES data can be found at  NCES Reference Library at https://nces.ed.gov/ccd/reference_library.asp
